Award.AwardTitle: A Longitudinal Study of the Effects of K-8 Mathematics Teacher Preparation on Teacher Knowledge, Teaching Practices, and Student Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The five-year project seeks to: (1) refine a developing theory of teacher preparation; (2) examine empirically the relationships among teacher preparation, teacher learning, teaching practice, and student learning; and (3) understand the conditions under which teachers use the knowledge and skills acquired during preparation and during their first few years of teaching to improve their practice. Utilizing a longitudinal design and following two cohorts of teachers as they transition from mathematics teacher preparation programs into classroom teaching, the project will study how preparation programs, field conditions, and selected contextual variables affect the implementation of effective classroom mathematics teaching. Research methods will include a planned mix of controlled experiments, small-sample replications, and case studies. Data collection will include both large-sample written assessments and small-sample recurring observations and interviews. By focusing on selected rational number topics and the middle grades 7-8, researchers will compare the effects of two different preparation programs, one designed for elementary/middle school (grades K-8) and the other for secondary school (grades 7-12).

The project addresses the fundamental issue of how teachers can be taught to teach effectively from the preservice to the inservice stage. Its longitudinal aspect involves documenting growth in effective mathematics teaching from the time participants are in schools as preservice undergraduate education majors to many years after when they are in schools as professional, inservice mathematics teachers. The project takes the view that effective mathematics teaching in the schools does not only require strengthening teachers' mathematics content but also addressing ways in which they can be supported in dealing with contextual variables (institutional constraints) that either hinder or support effective implementation of effective teaching practices. The project also addresses the following controversial issue facing mathematics teacher education research today: Does having more mathematics content (in the case of secondary mathematics majors) than mathematical content knowledge for teaching mathematics (in the case of elementary and middle school majors) a sufficient condition for effectively teaching mathematics (and vice-versa), in particular, fractions?

POR.DRECONTENT:
Every year, the United States spends millions of dollars preparing thousands of teachers, with little evidence of effectiveness. Until there is sufficient empirical data on how teachers learn to teach effectively, the U.S. has no choice but to make crucial decisions based on best guesses.

The goal of this longitudinal study was to help build a knowledge base for designing effective mathematics teacher preparation programs by investigating relationships between mathematics content courses and graduates' knowledge, skills, and classroom practice. The aim was to move beyond best guesses by contributing to a more informed research basis for making critical decisions about preparing mathematics teachers. Research participants were two cohorts of graduates from a K-6 teacher preparation program, followed from graduation to three to four years after graduation.  A total of 132 graduates participated in the study.

The mathematics portion of the preparation program consisted of three mathematics content courses and one mathematics methods course. Before the study began, the mathematics content courses had been carefully designed, tested, and refined over many years.  In order to provide more effective learning opportunities for students, mathematics education faculty and doctoral students had collaboratively developed, tested, and revised detailed, shared lesson plans for each class session. Each section of the same course used the same lesson plans to provide similar learning opportunities to all students. Previous empirical studies indicated the courses had become increasingly more effective over time.

This study focused on the effects of the first two mathematics content courses, taken by prospective teachers in their freshman year in the program. These courses focus on developing number and operation concepts.

Participants completed a set of paper-and-pencil tasks, an online video task, and a lesson planning task. The paper-and-pencil tasks were designed to measure participants' mathematics knowledge for teaching. For example, one task asked participants to analyze a student's written solution to a mathematics problem and infer what the student did, and did not, understand about the concepts embedded in the problem. The video task measured participants' skill in analyzing a classroom segment in which a teacher and students were interacting about a mathematical concept or procedure. The lesson planning task assessed participants' ability to design a lesson to introduce a standard arithmetic procedure in a way that would support students’ understanding of the underlying concepts.  

Four analogous versions of each task were administered to all participants – one for each of four mathematics topics from the U.S. elementary mathematics curriculum. Three of the topics (multiplication of two-digit whole numbers, subtraction of fractions, and division of fractions) were carefully developed in the program and classified as "target" topics. The fourth topic (finding the mean of a small set of whole numbers) was not addressed in the program and was thus considered a "control" topic. Participants completed the same set of tasks each summer, from graduation to three to four years beyond graduation.  In addition, each year a small sample of graduates were observed teaching classroom lessons on one of the target topics and on the control topic.

Results indicate that graduates' performances on the paper-and-pencil tasks, the video task, and the lesson planning task involving the three target topics were consistently higher than their performance on analogous tasks involving the control topic. Not all differences were significant, but whenever significant differences were found, they favored the target topics. This was true even as graduates moved several years beyond their preparation program. Alternative explanations for these differences, such as professional development on the target topics after graduation, or teaching the target topics more frequently, were ruled out by information collected from the graduates. Case studies of graduates who were observed teaching confirmed that graduates retained, and used in their teaching, the mathematics they studied as freshmen, six to seven years earlier.

Thus, the longitudinal data revealed persistent, positive relationships between the mathematics knowledge for teaching that graduates developed in the program and their later performance. In addition, some data suggested that the more time prospective teachers spent studying a topic during the preparation program, the more likely they were to apply their knowledge of this topic to complete the tasks.

Findings suggest that appropriately designed mathematics courses for prospective teachers can have a significant effect on the mathematical knowledge and skill for teaching that graduates retain and use, even six to seven years after completing such courses. It appears that appropriately designed courses need to devote considerable time developing prospective teachers' understanding of key mathematical topics; survey courses, in which many topics are covered briefly, are unlikely to have a significant impact. If results from this study are replicated in future studies, then mathematics teacher educators will need to make difficult choices about what knowledge and skills are most important for prospective teachers to acquire.
